child.pub-comments: Betoi consists of several dialects or related languages: Airico, Betoi, Ele, Jirara, Lolaca, Situfa (Adelaar 2004:161); their status is not certain. Possibly a small family. "Loukotka (1968), Suarez (1974) and even Numuendaju (1981) all include Betoi in Chibchan (which for them includes Paesan), and Greenberg locates it more specifically in Paczan." (Kaufman, 63)

child.pub-comments: Culle is sometimes thought be related to Cholonan (see for example Kaufman 2007:69), but is so poorly documented a determination of its genetic affinity is difficult; the primary sources on the language are two word lists, one of 19 words, the other of 43 (Adelaar 2004:401-3).

child.pub-comments: Rivet (1943) proposed several relatives of Candoshi among now extinct languages of northern Peru, most unconvincing. Chirino has only four words recorded, but they seem sufficient to favor the Candoshi connection (Adelaar 2004:406, Torero 2002:280-3). Loukotka (1968:156) also had several others, including Chirino, in his “Murato stock”: Shapra (Iñuru, Zapa), Pinche (Llepa, Uchpa, Avaza [see Taushiro, below, now considered an independent isolate]), Sacata, and Rabona. Speakers: 3000

child.pub-comments: Taushiro was missed by most classifiers except Tovar (1961, though not repeated in Tovar and Tovar 1984), who grouped it with Omurano. Kaufman (1994:63) notes certain lexical resemblances “that tend to support Tovar’s claim.” “Pinche” is grouped with Candoshi by Loukotka (1968) and Tovar and Tovar (1984), but Taushiro is considered Zaparoan in Kaufman (1994:63). Kaufman (1994:63) also reports Taushiro lexical similarities with Candoshi and with Omurano. "On the basis of a certain amount of lexical evidence, it seems that Taushiro might be related to both Omurano and Kandoshi, and more closely to the former." (69) Speakers: 7

(Migliazza 1978, 1980.)

child.pub-comments: Loukotka (1968:259) gave as languages in his “Yurimangui stock”: Yurimangui, Timba, Lili, Yolo (Paripazo), Jamundi, and Puscajae (Pile). "'Yurimangui' is the name of a river in Colombia, department of Valle de Cauca. Loukotka (1943) placed Yurimangi in 'Chibchan' as a 'mixed language'. Rivet (1943) tried to show that Yuirmangi belongs to the Hokan stock. Greenberg (1987) follows him in this. Swadesh (1959) sets up a macro-Zamuco of 88 centuries' differentiation including Awishiri=Tekiraka, Samúkoan, Charrúan and Ofayé. Quite obviously the linguistic kin of Yurimangi are far to seek. Yurimangi is dead and poorly documented." (Kaufman, 63)

child.pub-comments: Chono is extinct, from the northern Kaweskar region, very poorly attested, principally from a catequism without translation. There has been confusion about its classification. Some reportedly Chono materials make it appear to be a variant of Kaweskar (Alacaluf), but the material presented by Bausani (1975) from the eighteenth century catechism shows it to be different from Kaweskar (Adelaar 2004:553), suggesting that it is a distinct language, unrelated to others of the region. Chono is also sometimes equated with Aksanás, another confusing term. Aksanás as identified today is one name for Northern Kaweskar. Loukotka (1968:44) had an Aksanás stock with two languages, Chono (Caucau) and Kaueskar (Aksanás), not connected with his Alacaluf “isolated language” (Loukotka 1968:43). Aksaná(s) is left out of this classification, on the assumption that Clairis (1978:32, 1985:756) is correct in showing that the assumed Aksaná(s) language (not Kaweskar) does not really exist.

child.pub-comments: Puquina was one of the three languages that was recognized in 1575 as a lengua general in colonial Peru, used for administration and for religion. It had great prestige, but in spite of that soon became extinct. There is an old long-standing misunderstanding according to which Puquina is considered to be closely related with Uru-Chipaya, although they have almost nothing in common. This error comes from the fact that Uru and Chipaya each have often been called “Puquina” (Adelaar 1989:43, 175, 252, Mason 1950:224; Olson 1964:314). This error was pointed out and corrected long ago and repeated frequently (see Chamberlain 1910, Ibarra Grasso 1958:10, 1964:37-3, and for details Campbell 1997:189, 210). In spite of this, the mistaken classification of Puquina with Uru-Chipaya has often been repeated (for example, Crequi-Montfort and Rivet 1925-7, Greenberg 1987:xx; Noble 1965, Tovar 1961:47-9; etc.; see also Mason 1950:224-5). Callahuaya (Machaj-Juyai, Collahuaya, Pohena) is a jargonized (or mixed) language based predominantly on lexical items from Puquina and morphology from Quechua, used by male curers who live in a few villages in the provinces of Muñecas and Bautista Saavedra, Department of La Paz, Bolivia, but who travel widely throughout this part of South America to practice their curing profession. It has generally been considered to be a much changed variety of (or relative of) Puquina.

child.pub-comments: Adelaar (2004:321) "for the time being, the Mochica language most be considered as a language isolate." It is often linked with extinct Cañar (Cañari) and Puruhá (Puruguay) of Ecuador, but there is virtually no attestation of these languages. (See Cerrón-Palomino 1995.) Kaufman (2009:69), nevertheless, gives a "Chimuan family" made up of: Mochica, Kanyari, and Puruwá. Loukotka’s (1968:26-2) "Chimú stock" included Chimú and the following in his "Northern Languages" branch: Ayahuaca, Calva, Tumbi (Tumbez), Puná (Lapuna), Colonche, Chanduy, Tacame (Atacamez) [now considered Esmeralda, and independent isolate], Chongón, Coaque, Manabi (Manta) Huancavilca, Cañari, and Puruhá (Puruguai). Mochika was one of the major languages of pre-Columbian South America and was fairly well documented by Carrera (17th century) and Middendorf (19th century).

child.pub-comments: Martins (2005:341) mentions that the data point to a probable Makúan affinity for Hodï, possibly connected with the Kakwa group of languages, but this is unconfirmed. (See Mattei-Miller et al. 1996.) The Ethnologue mentions possible connections to Yamomanan and Sáliban languages (www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=yau).] Dixon and Aikhenvald (1999:20) list "Hoti" among the "few languages that we say nothing about, for the simple reason that almost nothing is know about them." Speakers: 300

child.pub-comments: Yurí is poorly known and probably extinct; the evidence does not support earlier attempts to group it with either Arawakan or Cariban. Kaufman (2007:68) places it with Tikuna and Munichi in his “Juri-Tikuna stock.”
